title: Spanish onshore wind growth set to slump 40% in 2025 – lobby
subtitle: (Montel) Spain is set to build just over 600 MW of new onshore wind generation capacity next year, around 40% less than in 2024, amid an unfavourable economic situation, wind lobby AEE said on Wednesday.
body:
This figure compared to “just over” 1,000 MW of new wind capacity expected in 2024 and 607 MW in 2023, AEE CEO Juan Virgilio Marquez said in a press conference to present a study.
“Many wind developers” in Spain have delayed project developments until 2027-28 amid economic doubts in the sector, he said.
Investors saw increasing “uncertainty and caution” resulting from weak power demand, which can lead to zero prices when renewables generation is abundant, as well as supply chain tensions and new local taxes, Marquez added.
Heikki Willstedt, AEE’s director of energy policy and climate change, also pointed to costs being raised by higher interest rates.
An extension to renewables permitting deadlines was approved last year to ease administrative bottlenecks.
Behind scheduleThe typical annual growth rate in the Spanish wind sector was around 1.5 GW, but this would need to “double or triple” if the country is to reach its target of 62 GW of wind capacity by 2030, Marquez said. 
“If power demand does not increase, there will obviously be no idle renewable generation waiting for demand to arrive,” he added.
Spanish wind developers had around 9.5 GW in projects for which all the permits were in place, and which were only awaiting financing. An additional 12 GW were still pending construction authorisations, Marquez said.
AEE reiterated that it expected to see Spain’s first auction for offshore wind called by the end of next year, probably in the Canary Islands, with around 250 MW of capacity.
